Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Story: My phone buzzed with a frantic call from Sam, my oldest friend. His car had broken down on the highway, miles from anywhere, and he sounded scared. “Can you come get me? Please, I don’t know who else to call.” I glanced at the clock—almost midnight. I was about to grab my keys when my work phone chimed. An assistant from the firm, new and eager, messaged me: “Can you send me the client files for the Miller case? I need to prep for tomorrow.” I knew she didn’t have clearance, and sharing those files would violate every ethical rule I’d sworn to uphold. But she was insistent, and the partners expected me to be a team player, to help the new staff settle in. My heart pounded. Sam needed me, but so did my job. I felt pulled in two directions—one by loyalty and friendship, the other by duty and professional integrity. I stood in my hallway, keys in one hand, phone in the other, torn between the desperate voice of my friend and the silent, weighty expectations of my profession.
